>>fc62e409-49d9-4a5c-9fd1-6ae310e93cdd
You know what to do.

VPNs are retarded. Just go in the ZeroNet FAQ and learn how to set it to use an external Tor with obfs4 bridges. Then set Tor to Always and trackers proxy to Tor and everything will work just fine as long as you have the Millchan patch installed.

>>71a5c045-553b-4e10-882c-3bfaa684823b
It doesn't give you any more security than not using one. You're just going from trusting your Internet service provider not to give out your identity to LE, to trusting your proxy service provider not to give out your identity to LE. Both obviously do so. Otherwise they would've already drowned in lawyer fees because every LE agency on the planet would've sued them for Contempt.
About the only benefit of a VPN is that they hide your geographical location from the other endpoint.

To test a new install I have to close my actual ZeroNet install each time I launch the new one. But you obviously can't do  that because then you might interfere with the propagation of the changes.

>>0916a6b7-6b83-4754-973a-6fe72669e39c

>>8c996f8e-fb9f-4551-a5bf-bc40c25513cc
>permissions 	Per-user permissions. (false = banned user)
So it's only blacklist apparently, and setting it to true doesn't do anything.
Maybe there is a way to stop people being able to sign their own posts using 
[code]
"08chan": ["1NwwLdiFBcVAA4jXQ712ZtQfDHEMvk8BiD"]
[/code]
That's why it might be important to understand what that string actually is.

There's a property in the example in the docs that seems interesting
[code]
    "cert_signers_pattern": "1Zero[0-9].*",
[/code]

== ATTENTION ADMIN ==
POSSIBLE SOLUTION HERE https://anonfile.com/D9N4P227nf/content_json
ANONFILE BECAUSE OVER THE SIZE LIMIT FOR PASTEBIN
If this doesn't work I have some other ideas, but let's try this one first.

>>4abbb34e-e1d1-4d6e-ab7f-dbade3499a83
And you know that, how? Source?
** Or are you just making it up? **

>>8184c17e-2fbb-49f6-9342-10ccad1c1c3d
>See that line at the bottom listing 08chan under signers? That line is what enabled self-signed certs from 08chan. Thats what we need to turn off.
If you turn it off then there's no possible way to display those messages.
My solution relies in enabling that cert, and then not downloading the messages that aren't coming from a subset of the people using that cert. The obvious problem is that contents.json might still be downloaded, making it possibility to spam content.jsons into the users folder. But I see no other way. At least they won't be able to post, and if we see the users folder growing uncontrollably because of users without data.json we can do something about it. Maybe we can blacklist content.json files somehow.
The second obvious problem is that 
[code]
  "permission_rules": {
   ".*@08chan": {
    "max_size": 0,
    "files_allowed": "",
    "files_allowed_optional": ""
   },
[/code]
might just outright ban all .*@08chan certs and make the manual "permissions": { ... } part useless, but if that was the case I doubt permissions would exist at all (unless they are useful to override the default permissions, but not the ones specified by regexes?).
The third obvious problem might be that for some reason permission_rules seem to be completely ignored by the software. Previously when you enabled self signed certs for a few minutes, we were still able to post using ZeroBit. Hopefully it is because the default permissions (which are, as almost everything in this piece of shit software, undocumented) are too lenient, and the above rulset fixes that. This problem should be mutually exclusive with the previous one, since if defaults are too lenient the "permissions" property wouldn't be needed to ovverride them, which would mean they were useful to override permission_rules.
>Edit: Looks like the proper syntax is double backslashes? This is how the main line for the cert signers is structured.
Oh, yeah, right. That was an artifact from pasting the stuff in a .py file without escaping the backslashes. Replace them in your favorite text editor with the correct ones.

My plan B if this fails was to convert everything that is now in the permissions into regexes and stuff them in permission_rules. But I'm not gonna lie, it's gonna be tricky, because ZeroNet only allows 250 char long regexes because of DDoS reasons. I have an idea for splitting them all in multiple rules though.
But if we're affected by problem number 3 with the current solution (permisison_rules being ignored) we're screwed, because this plan B won't work either.

>>1d618edd-f760-4e5c-86a3-773e3c2178bb
>Trying to fix the syntax now. gedit doesn't want to find and replace the \. characters for some reason, even with the file saved as text. Stand by.
Ok, if you can't fix tell me and I'll replace them in Notepad++.
>If it helps, we never went back to just the 08chan certs when I had them enabled, only along side ZeroID because I didn't want anyone to get pissed trying to post while I was working on it. I think you're onto something, with the "permissions" able to override the main code lines as exceptions. Its worth a shot, right?
Yeah, I don't mean in the cert_signers. I mean your code looked like
[code]
  "permission_rules": {
   ".*@08chan": {
    "files_allowed": "data.json",
    "files_allowed_optional": "(src\\/)?.{40}(-thumb)?\\.(png|jpeg|jpg|gif|webm|mp4|ogg|mp3|pdf|epub)(\\.piecemap\\.msgpack)?",
    "max_size": 5000000
   }
  }
[/code]
You'll notice it only mentions .*@08chan (self signed certs), it says nothing about .*@zeroid.bit users. I hope the reason it worked was because if you don't specify anything everyone is given unlimited file size and types, and not because permission_rules is ignored altogether in the code, because if that's the case then the problem just got 10 times harder.

>>203c17e7-7cad-4806-8f55-999607759cbe
>The users/content.json file didn't update the first time.
Yeah, I never saw the intended file on my end. Why didn't it update? How do you even push changes to it? I thought you just modified your own file and pushed sign. Do you mean it failed to show up in a secondary instance?
Honestly I don't understand how the signing process works. How can you sign a file and modify something '''inside''' the file (adding the signature to it), without breaking the signature, since now it's a different file?
>I closed Zeronet, edited it and restarted, and it threw this error when trying to sign and publish:
What did you change? Can you show the resulting file?

>>203c17e7-7cad-4806-8f55-999607759cbe
Try the prettified version
https://anonfile.com/Q8rcQd20ne/content_json

I hereby declare myself the Supreme Enlightened of 08Channel.
** While the frontend denies me even creating the message, I don't know what might be done by bypassing it, for example, by hacking a ZeroNet client to ignore size limits. I imagine the other clients check the size limits before downloading too, so spamming using self-signed accounts should be effectively impossible. **

posts.body:
>>6d59eeb4-d973-48d6-964f-6b79d1af594f
Well, the signature is technically valid (we accept the CA that produced it in cert_signers). It's just that there's a config file signed with a valid signature too (and a more important one, yours, not just the one that everybody has) telling the clients (in theory) not to download the message if it's over 0 bytes.
Oh, and I found out how signatures are produced. They're performed over the normalized JSON file with the node that holds the signature omitted (https://zeronet.io/docs/site_development/content_json/#signs).
The way I suspect self-signed certs are produced is there's a private key hard-coded into the ZeroNet client for an also hardcoded user's public key (1NwwLdiFBcVAA4jXQ712ZtQfDHEMvk8BiD) which is then referred to as the domain (08chan) and allows clients to sign .*@08chan certs. Otherwise if the key pair was randomly generated it'd be hard to distinguish certs signed by the users themselves from the certs signed by an actual CA.

>>62fb706c-5e60-4e5a-81c0-50c50db4328d
Try installing Millchan
https://anonfile.com/Kc07Bf2bnf/update_08chan_s_Millchan_version_201908081621_zip
If that doesn't fix it and you're using Tor then enable obfs4 bridges by routing through Tor Browser.
https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq/#how-to-make-tor-work-if-my-isp-or-goverment-blocks-it
Otherwise close ZeroNet and delete all the *.db files on it.

>>9f40e719-61b0-458b-9669-f928b051ec5d
Well I don't see who you replied to either.

>>920cca11-8b72-471c-9b0e-a896696d0c48
== With respect to the Millchan issue ==
I '''am''' experiencing massive slowdowns on it. But I suspect it might be just because of downloading so much stuff. I got 18G on it currently.
In any case it '''is''' more bloated (the interface is anyways) than this board's version.
Since they decided to go the pozz way with pretty animations and shit instead of just working, **we** might need to do further development to get it to an usable level. If the board keeps growing and capturing stragglers that haven't yet found their way here, it might be possible to assemble a team to do some optimization. But right now I'm afraid there isn't the manpower available.

>>999422a0-5aae-40ba-a416-7fcc53edca16
That's just because your client hasn't generated the self-signed cert (and you probably ''can't'' generate it, because you can't post in the first place).
>It might just be a coincidence. I notice that even though I'm also on a ZeroID, my own [m] shows it coming from @08chan, but on a cert that I know I got from ZeroID. The ID is for this site, but was created by ZeroID.
Weird.

>Honestly I would much rather parse nuMillchan's code for their fix for TOR images, use that, and leave the rest of the site alone. I don't think anyone would be happy with namefagging going on, for instance. And we'd have to gut their CSS and other things just to get it all right.
They supposedly fixed a muting bug too where files weren't deleted or something.
The namefagging stuff should be possible to prevent by enabling "forced anonymity" by default and removing the option from the settings. ** Although personally I'd add even more ID tracking features like seeing all posts or at least copying a user's ID to the clipboard, since personally I don't care for security through obscurity for myself, and sometimes I might want to dig up something from some user and I'd hate to have to do a full text search on the users folder.**
I don't care for how the site looks either as long as it's readable, but it shouldn't be too hard to adapt the old CSS files. I think they actually look mostly right already when applied to the updated engine except for a few defects here and there.
I'm not empathetic for the normalfaggy desire of familiar looks and illusion of anonymity. Making it too familiar would attract more retards to the site.

>>eb9cd92b-5206-435e-a902-c99ae6d8167a
Wait it out. Maybe everybody has your files already, so they don't need your seed.
